Preprocessing 
Techniques
By:-
Dr . Esraa Abdalla

Importance of Preprocessing
Text mining relies heavily 
on preprocessing 
techniques to convert 
raw unstructured data 
into structured formats.
Different preprocessing 
techniques are required 
for text mining compared 
to traditional data 
mining.

Why is T ext Preprocessing 
Important?
Raw text is messy 
(typos, special 
characters, inconsistent 
formatting).
Ensures uniformity & 
consistency for 
machine learning 
models.
Improves accuracy, 
efficiency, and 
processing speed.

Overview of T ext Preprocessing 
Steps
1. Text Cleaning – Removing unwanted elements.
2. Tokenization – Splitting text into words.
3. Sentence Segmentation – Dividing text into sentences.
4. Normalization – Converting words to standard forms.
5. Stopword Removal – Filtering out unimportant words.
6. Stemming & Lemmatization – Reducing words to root forms.

Challenges in T ext 
Preprocessing
Different languages require different 
techniques.
Noise in text from social media, OCR, 
and scanned documents.
Variability in sentence structure, 
punctuation, and abbreviations.

How Machines Read T ext
Computers process text as numbers 
(binary/Unicode).
Challenges: Encoding mismatches, character 
corruptions, special symbols.

Goals of Preprocessing
Reduce 
redundancy and 
inconsistency in 
text.
01
Convert text 
into machine-
readable format.
02
Improve the 
efficiency of NLP 
pipelines.
03

Categories of Preprocessing 
T echniques
Task-Oriented Approaches: Focus on specific tasks 
like extracting titles and authors from documents.
Formal Frameworks: Include classification schemes, 
probabilistic models, and rule-based systems.

Combining T echniques
Techniques can be mixed and matched for 
different applications.
Algorithms used in preprocessing are often not 
specific to particular tasks and can solve 
multiple problems.

Task-Oriented Approaches
Preparatory Processing: Converts raw input (e.g., 
PDF, scanned pages) into a text stream.
General Purpose NLP Tasks: Include tokenization, 
POS tagging, and syntactic parsing.
Problem-Dependent Tasks: Include text 
categorization and information extraction.

General Purpose NLP T asks
Tokenization: Breaking text into 
sentences and words.
POS Tagging: Annotating words with 
parts of speech based on context.

General Purpose NLP T asks
Syntactical Parsing: 
Analyzing sentence 
structure using 
constituency and 
dependency grammars.
Shallow Parsing: 
Producing partial 
analyses of sentences 
for speed and 
robustness.

T okenization
Breaking text into sentences and 
words.
Challenges in identifying sentence 
boundaries in English.
Extracting token features like 
capitalization, digits, punctuation.

POS Tagging
Annotating words with parts of speech 
based on context.
Categories of POS tags (e.g., Noun, 
Verb, Adjective).
Morphological analysis and sequence 
of stems (lemmas).

Syntactical Parsing
Full syntactical analysis of sentences.
Constituency Grammars: Describe syntactical 
structure in terms of phrases.
Dependency Grammars: Focus on direct relations 
between words.

Shallow Parsing
Compromise between speed and depth of analysis.
Producing parts of sentences that are easy and 
unambiguous.
Suitable for information extraction due to speed 
and robustness.

Parts of Speech
From the earliest linguistic traditions (Yaska and Panini 5th C. 
BCE, Aristotle 4th C. BCE), the idea that words can be classified 
into grammatical categories
• part of speech, word classes, POS, POS tags
8 parts of speech attributed to Dionysius Thrax of Alexandria (c. 
1st C. BCE): 
• noun, verb, pronoun, preposition, adverb, conjunction, 
participle, article 
• These categories are relevant for NLP today.

Problem-Dependent Tasks
Text Categorization: Tagging documents with 
concepts or keywords.
Information Extraction (IE): Extracting relevant 
information and presenting it in a structured format.

Tagging documents with a small 
number of concepts or keywords.
Manually prepared, closed set of 
keywords.
Hierarchy relation between 
keywords.

Extracting relevant 
information and 
presenting it in a 
structured format.
Distinguishing IE from 
information retrieval 
(search).
IE aims at pinpointing 
relevant information 
and presenting it in a 
tabular format.

Core T ext Mining Operations
Pattern-Discovery Algorithms
Concept Selection and Proportion
Concept Distributions
Frequent Concept Sets
Associations
Interesting Patterns
Analyzing Document Collections Over Time

Pattern-Discovery Algorithms
Distributions: Identifying the proportion of 
documents labeled with specific concepts.
Frequent and Near Frequent Sets: Finding sets of 
concepts that frequently co-occur.
Associations: Discovering relationships between 
sets of concepts.

Concept Selection and Proportion
Concept Selection: Referring to subsets of documents 
labeled with specific concepts.
Concept Proportion: Calculating the fraction of documents 
labeled with certain concepts.
Conditional Concept Proportion: Proportion of documents 
labeled with one concept that are also labeled with another.

Concept Distributions
Concept Proportion 
Distribution: Proportion of 
documents labeled with each 
concept in a set.
Conditional Concept 
Proportion Distribution: 
Proportion of documents 
labeled with a set of concepts 
that are also labeled with 
another concept.

Frequent Concept Sets
Frequent Sets: Sets of concepts that 
appear together in a minimum number 
of documents.
Near Frequent Sets: Sets of concepts 
that frequently co-occur but not as 
often as frequent sets.

Associations
Association Rules: Rules indicating 
that the presence of one set of 
concepts implies the presence of 
another set.
Maximal Associations: Specialized 
associations relevant to one concept 
but not another.

Interesting Patterns
Concept Distribution 
Distance: Measuring 
the distance between 
two concept 
distributions.
Concept Proportion 
Distance: Measuring 
the difference between 
two distributions at a 
particular point.

Analyzing Document Collections Over Time
Trend Analysis: Analyzing concept distribution 
behavior over time.
Ephemeral Associations: Temporary relationships 
between concepts over a fixed time span.
Deviation Detection: Identifying anomalies that do 
not fit a defined standard case.

Using Background Knowledge for T ext 
Mining
Domain Ontologies
Domain Lexicons
Integrating Background Knowledge

Domain Ontologies
Definition: A set 
of all classes of 
interest and their 
relationships 
within a domain.
Examples: 
WordNet for the 
English language, 
Gene Ontology 
for biological 
processes.

Domain Lexicons
Definition: Names of 
domain concepts and 
their relations.
Usage: Normalizing 
concept identifiers and 
extracting semantic 
relationships.

Integrating Background Knowledge
Constraints: Using 
background knowledge 
to limit pattern 
abundance and create 
meaningful queries.
Hierarchical 
Representations: 
Creating consistent 
hierarchies for 
concepts.

Language)

▪Query Interface

T ext Language)

patterns.

Finding associations 
between sets of

What is Computer Vision?
• A process that produces from images of the external 
world a description that is useful to the viewer and not 
cluttered with irrelevant information (Marr)
• Construction of explicit , meaningful descriptions of 
physical objects from images (Ballard and Brown )
• To make useful decisions about real physical objects and 
scenes based on sensed images (Shapiro and Stockman)

- Plays well with scalars
- x(A*B) = (xA)*B = A*(xB)

Another edge detector:
- Image is a function:

- Think in terms of fourier transform
- Edges are high frequency changes
- Maybe we want to find edges of a specific size (i.e. specific 
frequency)
58

Difference of Gaussian 
(DoG)
- Gaussian is a low pass filter
- Strongly reduce components with frequency f < σ
- (g*I) low frequency components
- I - (g*I) high frequency components
- g(σ1)*I - g(σ2)*I
- Components in between these frequencies
- g(σ1)*I - g(σ2)*I = [g(σ1) - g(σ2)]*I

Threshold edges
- Still some noise
- Only want strong edges
- 2 thresholds, 3 cases
- R > T: strong edge
- R < T but R > t: weak edge
- R < t: no edge
- Why two thresholds?

Features!
- Highly descriptive local regions
- Ways to describe those regions
- Useful for:
- Matching
- Recognition
- Detection
89

What makes a good feature?
- Want to find patches in image that are useful or have some 
meaning
- For objects, want a patch that is common to that object but not 
in general
- For panorama stitching, want patches that we can find easily in 
another image of same place
- Good features are unique!
- Can find the “same” feature easily
- Not mistaken for “different” features
90

How close are two patches?
- Sum squared difference
- Images I, J
- Σx,y (I(x,y) - J(x,y))2
91

How can we find unique patches?
- Say we are stitching a panorama
- Want patches in image to match to other image
- Need to only match one spot
